Award.AwardTitle: IGERT: Geometry and Dynamics -- Integrated Education in the Mathematical Sciences

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This Integrative Graduate Education and Research Traineeship (IGERT) award supports an interdisciplinary training program for Ph.D. students at Brandeis University, carried out in partnership with the New England Center for Complex Systems (NECSI). The goal is to create a group of mathematical scientists with the computational skills, intellectual flexibility, and global perspective needed to attack pressing problems in pure science, applied science, and public policy that require a mathematically sophisticated, interdisciplinary approach.

Intellectual Merit: Fundamental problems in the theory of fundamental particles, quantum gravity, the science of materials, the emergence of cognition, disease epidemiology, and economic forecasting all draw from a set of common mathematical concepts and techniques in geometry, complex classical and quantum systems, and probability theory. Students trained in a variety of mathematical techniques, broadly educated in the applications of these techniques, and experienced in communicating their ideas across disciplines will best be able to respond to new scientific problems whose solution requires advanced mathematics, sophisticated modeling, and the management of large data sets. The IGERT program will therefore include: hands-on experience through interdisciplinary research rotations; interdisciplinary coursework; co-advisors outside of the students? discipline; intensive NECSI-led summer institutes; an IGERT seminar series; and the opportunity for internships at the International Center for the Theoretical Sciences in Bangalore, India. Broader Impacts: Students will learn to communicate their work to prospective science students and the public via public lectures, the Brandeis Science Posse program, and the Acton Discovery Center.

IGERT is an NSF-wide program intended to meet the challenges of educating U.S. Ph.D. scientists and engineers with the interdisciplinary background, deep knowledge in a chosen discipline, and the technical, professional, and personal skills needed for the career demands of the future. The program is intended to catalyze a cultural change in graduate education by establishing innovative new models for graduate education and training in a fertile environment for collaborative research that transcends traditional disciplinary boundaries.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Brandeis IGERT program in Geometry and Dynamics brought together researchers in a wide range of the theoretical and mathematical sciences -- chemistry, computer science, economics, mathematics, neuroscience, and physics -- to identify mathematical structures and techniques common to different areas of science, and provide graduate trainees with a broad foundation that would enable them to communicate across disciplines. They did this through a variety of connected educational activities which then informed their own research. To supervise this, the IGERT program consisted of five co-Principal Investigators from across the sciences at Brandeis: IGERT director Albion Lawrence (Physics), Bulbul Chakraborty (Physics), Blake LeBaron (International Business School), Paul Miller (Neuroscience), and Daniel Ruberman (Mathematics). In addition there were numerous faculty associates who lectured and supervised IGERT trainees.

The first main component of the IGERT program were interdisciplinary courses: in addition to existing courses with an interdisciplinary audience, two courses were designed or re-designed for the IGERT program.  Co-PIs Albion Lawrence (Physics) and Daniel Ruberman (Mathematics) designed and taught a course in of a branch of mathematics known as differential geometry, to the question of how cats turn themselves while falling, and to a quantum-mechanical phenomenon known as Berry's phase.  Faculty associate Mark Adler (Mathematics) and co-PI Paul Miller re-designed and co-taught a mathematics course in "stochastic processes" -- phenomena which include a random element -- so as to include applications from neuroscience and economics.

The second main component was a seminar series during the school year, by external speakers and Brandeis trainees, combined with a yearly summer institute with longer-form pedagogical lectures on interdisciplinary topics by speakers from inside and outside of Brandeis.  By bringing different subjects (and the lecturers) into close contact, the summer institutes highlighted deep connections between diverse fields: for example, relationships between the motion of barely rigid materials and the climactic phenomena known as El Nino.

The third main component was a partnership with the International Center for the Theoretical Sciences (ICTS) in Bangalore, India. This resulted in four IGERT trainees who worked as interns at various institutions in India; a group of Indian faculty who lectured at the 2015 summer institute; and a pair of very successful advanced institutes for graduate students , funded by a separate NSF grant, on "Thermalization: from glasses to black holes" in 2013 and "Classical and quantum information" in December 2016-January 2017.

The research of IGERT trainees, in areas with broad interdisciplinary interest, was the real success of this program. IGERT trainee Blake Stacey (Physics) did his thesis work on using information theory to understand complex phenomena, applying his insights to mathematical models of evolution. IGERT trainees Daniel Goldstein , co-PI Chakraborty, and postdoc Michael Giver (all Physics) studied pattern formation in collections of elements which oscillated by themselves but are then coupled to each other; IGERT trainee Naziru Awal studied the development of chaos in a pair of such coupled elements. IGERT trainee Dapeng "Max" Bi , with co-PI Chakraborty, fellow graduate student Sumantra Sarkar (all Physics), and additional collaborators form Brandeis, Duke, and Shanghai used concepts from quantum information theory to describe how granular systems such as sand can "jam" and cease to flow. IGERT trainee Biji Wong (Mathematics) developed new tools to study spaces important for string theory. IGERT trainees Gabriel Redner, Elias Putzig, and Caleb Wagner, with faculty associates Aparna Baskaran and Michael Hagan (all Physics) developed general theories for understanding "active materials" (materials built from components which consume energy), and mathematical techniques for studying them. IGERT trainee Jessica Lowell and faculty associate Jordan Pollack (Computer Science) studied algorithms developed through evolutionary processes and the influence of the task at hand on the structure of these algorithms. IGERT trainee Carl Merrigan (Physics), co-PI Chakraborty, and collaborators from U Mass Amherst and the ICTS developed a theory for the clogging and unclogging of granular materials near a narrow opening. IGERT trainee Rose Morris-Wright and faculty associate Ruth Charney (Mathematics) produced new nontrivial results in the field of geometric group theory. IGERT trainee Jonathan Harper, with faculty associate Matthew Headrick and graduate student Andrew Rolph (all in Physics) used forefront mathematical concepts from the theory of networks to obtain new results in the intersection of quantum information theory and string theory.

A major lasting institutional results were the development of formal and informal ties between Brandeis faculty. The most striking outcome of this was the development of an applied mathematics program, built in a highly interdisciplinary fashion.  Three new faculty have been hired in Mathematics, with the stipulation that each has some contact with other research at Brandeis; and an undergraduate applied mathematics major has been implemented, including a requirement that one take two courses outside of mathematics in the school of science or in Economics.
